2-8-410  Eleventh Ward.

The Eleventh Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of West 45th Street and South Racine Avenue; thence west on West 45th Street to South Ashland Avenue; thence north on South Ashland Avenue to West Pershing Road; thence west on West Pershing Road to South Western Boulevard; thence north on South Western Boulevard to West 34th Street; thence east on West 34th Street to South Hoyne Avenue; thence northwest on South Hoyne Avenue and South Hoyne Avenue extended to the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal; thence east on the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal and the centerline of the south branch of the Chicago River to the ramp immediately east of the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94); thence southeasterly and southerly along the ramp immediately east of the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94) to the Adlai East Stevenson Expressway (I-55); thence east on the Adlai East Stevenson Expressway (I-55) to the centerline of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad to the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad to West 35th Street; thence west on West 35th Street to South Wells Street extended; thence south on South Wells Street extended and South Wells Street to West 37th Street; thence west on West 37th Street to South Princeton Avenue; thence south on South Princeton Avenue to West Pershing Road; thence west on West Pershing Road to the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad to South Stewart Avenue; thence south on South Stewart Avenue to the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad to West 43rd Street; thence west on West 43rd Street to the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad to West 43rd Place extended; thence east on West 43rd Place extended to South Stewart Avenue; thence south on South Stewart Avenue to West 46th Street; thence west on West 46th Street to the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad; thence southeast on the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad to West 47th Street; thence west on West 47th Street to South Racine Avenue; thence north on South Racine Avenue to the place of beginning.

2-8-420  Twelfth Ward.

The Twelfth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of South California Boulevard and West 23rd Street; thence east on West 23rd Street to South Washtenaw Avenue; thence south on South Washtenaw Avenue to West 24th Street; thence east on West 24th Street to the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway; thence south on the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal; thence northeast on the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal to South Hoyne Avenue extended northwest; thence south on South Hoyne Avenue extended and South Hoyne Avenue to West 34th Street; thence west on West 34th Street to South Western Boulevard; thence south on South Western Boulevard to West Pershing Road; thence east on West Pershing Road to South Ashland Avenue; thence south on South Ashland Avenue to West 45th Street; thence west on West 45th Street to South Wolcott Avenue; thence south on South Wolcott Avenue to West 46th Street; thence west on West 46th Street to South Damen Avenue; thence south on South Damen Avenue to West 48th Street; thence west on West 48th Street to South Seeley Avenue; thence south on South Seeley Avenue to West 49th Street; thence west on West 49th Street to South Western Boulevard; thence south on South Western Boulevard to the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad; thence west and northwest on the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad to South Campbell Avenue extended; thence north on South Campbell Avenue extended and South Campbell Avenue to West 48th Street; thence west on West 48th Street to South Talman Avenue; thence north on South Talman Avenue to West 47th Street; thence west on West 47th Street to South Mozart Street; thence north on South Mozart Street to West 42nd Street; thence east on West 42nd Street to South California Avenue; thence north on South California Avenue to West Pershing Road; thence west on West Pershing Road to South Francisco Avenue; thence north on South Francisco Avenue to West 38th Street; thence west on West 38th Street to South Sacramento Avenue; thence south on South Sacramento Avenue to West 38th Place; thence west on West 38th Place to South Albany Avenue; thence south on South Albany Avenue to West Pershing Road; thence west on West Pershing Road to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway; thence north on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway to South Central Park Avenue extended; thence north on South Central Park Avenue extended to the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal; thence northeast along the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal to South Kedzie Avenue; thence north on South Kedzie Avenue to West 31st Street; thence west on West 31st Street to South Spaulding Avenue; thence north on South Spaulding Avenue to West 30th Street; thence east on West 30th Street to South Sawyer Avenue; thence north on South Sawyer Avenue to West 28th Street; thence east on West 25th Street to South Troy Street; thence north on South Troy Street to West 24th Street; thence east on West 24th Street to South Whipple Street; thence north on South Whipple Street to West Cermak Road; thence north along South Marshall Boulevard and South Sacramento Drive to West Ogden Avenue; thence northeast on West Ogden Avenue to South California Boulevard; thence south on South California Boulevard to the place of beginning.

2-8-430  Thirteenth Ward.

The Thirteenth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of South Austin Avenue and West 63rd Street; thence north on South Austin Avenue to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to South Central Avenue; thence south on South Central Avenue to West 63rd Street; thence east on West 63rd Street to South Cicero Avenue; thence north on South Cicero Avenue to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago; thence north on the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago to West 55th Street; thence east on West 55th Street to South Pulaski Road; thence south on South Pulaski Road to West 55th Place; thence east on West 55th Place to South Hamlin Avenue; thence south on South Hamlin Avenue to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway; thence south on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway to West 74th Place extended; thence west on West 74th Place extended and West 74th Place to South Pulaski Road; thence south on South Pulaski Road to West 83rd Street; thence west on West 83rd Street to South Cicero Avenue; thence north on South Cicero Avenue to West 65th Street; thence west on West 65th Street to South Narragansett Avenue; thence north on South Narragansett Avenue to West 64th Street; thence east on West 64th Street to South Melvina Avenue; thence north on South Melvina Avenue to West 63rd Street; thence east on West 63rd Street to the place of beginning.

2-8-440  Fourteenth Ward.

The Fourteenth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad and West 51st Street; thence west on West 51st Street and West 51st Street extended and West 51st Street to South Kedvale Avenue; thence north on South Kedvale Avenue to West 47th Street; thence west on West 47th Street to the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago; thence north on the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago to West 43rd Street; thence west on West 43rd Street to South Cicero Avenue; thence north on South Cicero Avenue to the Adlai E. Stevenson Expressway (I-55); thence southwest on the Adlai E. Stevenson Expressway (I-55) to the city limit line; thence north and east along the city limit line to the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago; thence south on the centerline of the Belt Railway of Chicago to the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal; thence northeast on the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal to South Central Park Avenue extended; thence south on South Central Park Avenue extended to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway; thence south on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway to West Pershing Road; thence east on West Pershing Road to South Albany Avenue; thence north on South Albany Avenue to West 38th Place; thence east on West 38th Place to South Sacramento Avenue; thence north on South Sacramento Avenue to West 38th Street; thence east on West 38th Street to South Francisco Avenue; thence south on South Francisco Avenue to West Pershing Road; thence east on West Pershing Road to South California Avenue; thence south on South California Avenue to West 42nd Street; thence west on West 42nd Street to South Mozart Street; thence south on South Mozart Street to West 47th Street; thence east on West 47th Street to South Talman Avenue; thence south on South Talman Avenue to West 48th Street; thence east on West 48th Street to South Campbell Avenue; thence south on South Campbell Avenue and South Campbell Avenue extended to the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad; thence southeast and east on the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad to South Western Avenue; thence south on South Western Avenue to West 55th Street; thence west on West 55th Street to South Francisco Avenue; thence south on South Francisco Avenue to West 59th Street; thence west on West 59th Street to South Hamlin Avenue; thence north on South Hamlin Avenue to West 55th Place; thence east on West 55th Place to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad; thence north on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-27; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-450  Fifteenth Ward.

The Fifteenth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of South Laflin Street and West 58th Street; thence south on South Laflin Street to West 62nd Street; thence west on West 62nd Street to South Marshfield Avenue; thence south on South Marshfield Avenue to West 64th Street; thence east on West 64th Street to South Ashland Avenue; thence south on South Ashland Avenue to West 68th Street; thence west on West 68th Street to South Hamilton Avenue; thence north on South Hamilton Avenue to West Marquette Road; thence west on West Marquette Road to South Western Avenue; thence south on South Western Avenue to West 68th Street; thence west on West 68th Street to South Artesian Avenue; thence south on South Artesian Avenue to West 71st Street; thence west on West 71st Street to South Campbell Avenue; thence north on South Campbell Avenue to West 70th Street; thence west on West 70th Street to South Maplewood Avenue; thence north on South Maplewood Avenue to West Lithuanian Plaza Court; thence west on West Lithuanian Plaza Court to South California Avenue; thence north on South California Avenue to West Marquette Road; thence west on West Marquette Road to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway; thence north on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Railway to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad; thence north on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad to West 61st Street; thence east on West 61st Street to South Sacramento Avenue; thence north on South Sacramento Avenue to West 60th Street; thence east on West 60th Street to South Western Avenue; thence south on South Western Avenue to West 61st Street; thence east on West 61st Street and West 61st Street extended to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence northwest on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway; thence northeast on the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway to the centerline of West Garfield Boulevard; thence east on the centerline of West Garfield Boulevard to South Ashland Avenue; thence south on South Ashland Avenue to West 58th Street; thence east on West 58th Street to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-28; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-460  Sixteenth Ward.

The Sixteenth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

thence west on West 63rd Street to South Green Street; thence south on South Green Street to West 66th Street; thence east on West 66th Street to South Halsted Street; thence south on South Halsted Street to West Marquette Road; thence west on West Marquette Road to South Peoria Street; thence north on South Peoria Street to West 65th Street; thence west on West 65th Street to South Racine Avenue; thence north on South Racine Avenue to West 64th Street; thence west on West 64th Street to South Marshfield Avenue; thence north on South Marshfield Avenue to West 62nd Street; thence east on West 62nd Street to South Laflin Street; thence north on South Laflin Street to West 58th Street; thence west on West 58th Street to South Ashland Avenue; thence north on South Ashland Avenue to the centerline of West Garfield Boulevard; thence west on the centerline of West Garfield Boulevard to the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk and Southern Railway; thence southwest on the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk and Southern Railway to West 59th Street; thence west on West 59th Street to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence southeast on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to West 61st Street extended; thence west on West 61st Street extended and West 61st Street to South Western Avenue; thence north on South Western Avenue to West 60th Street; thence west on West 60th Street to South Sacramento Avenue; thence south on South Sacramento Avenue to West 61st Street; thence west on West 61st Street to the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad; thence north on the centerline of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to South Francisco Avenue; thence north on South Francisco Avenue to West 55th Street; thence east on West 55th Street to South Western Avenue; thence north on South Western Avenue to the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad; thence east on the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad to South Western Boulevard; thence north on South Western Boulevard to West 49th Street; thence east on West 49th Street to South Ashland Avenue; thence south on South Ashland Avenue to West 50th Street; thence east on West 50th Street to South Laflin Street; thence north on South Laflin Street to the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad; thence east on the centerline of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad to South Aberdeen Street; thence south on South Aberdeen Street to West 50th Street; thence east on West 50th Street to South Morgan Street; thence south on South Halsted Street to West 59th Street; thence east on West 59th Street to South Emerald Avenue; thence south on South Emerald Avenue to West 60th Street; thence east on West 60th Street to South Union Avenue; thence south on South Union Avenue to West 61st Street; thence east on West 61st Street to South Wallace Street; thence south on South Wallace Street to the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad to the place of beginning.

2-8-550  Twenty-fifth Ward.

The Twenty-fifth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94) and West Roosevelt Road; thence south on the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94) to West 16th Street; thence east on West 16th Street and West 16th Street extended to South Clark Street; thence south on South Clark Street to South Archer Avenue; thence southwest on South Archer Avenue to the centerline of the right-of-way line of the Northwest Illinois Rail Corporation (Metra); thence south on the centerline of the right-of-way line of the Northwest Illinois Rail Corporation (Metra) to the centerline of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad to the Adlai E. Stevenson Expressway (I-55); thence west on the Adlai E. Stevenson Expressway (I-55) to the ramp immediately east of the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94); thence northerly and northwesterly along the ramp immediately east of the Dan Ryan Expressway (I-90/94) to the centerline of the south branch of the Chicago River; thence southwest on the centerline of the south branch of the Chicago River and the centerline of the Sanitary and Ship Canal to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence north on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway; thence north on the centerline of the CSX Railroad and the Norfolk Southern Railway to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence northeast on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to West 19th Street; thence east on West 19th Street to South Western Avenue; thence north on South Western Avenue to West Polk Street; thence east on West Polk Street to South Oakley Boulevard; thence north on South Oakley Boulevard to West Harrison Street; thence south on South Leavitt Street and South Leavitt Street extended to West Roosevelt Road; thence west on West Roosevelt Road to South Oakley Boulevard; thence south on South Oakley Boulevard to West 14th Street extended; thence east on West 14th Street extended to South Bell Avenue extended; thence south on South Bell Avenue extended to the centerline of the Chicago Burlington and Quincy Railroad; thence east on the centerline of the Chicago Burlington and Quincy Railroad to South Hoyne Avenue extended; thence south on South Hoyne Avenue extended to West 16th Street; thence east on West 16th Street to the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; thence east on the centerline of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to South Wolcott Avenue; thence north on South Miller Street to West Roosevelt Road; thence west on West Roosevelt Road to South Racine Avenue; thence north on South Racine Avenue to West Cabrini Street; thence west on West Cabrini Street to South Ada Street; thence south on South Ada Street to West Taylor Street; thence west on West Taylor Street to South Laflin Street; thence north on South Laflin Street to West Polk Street; thence west on West Polk Street to South Ashland Avenue; thence north on South Ashland Avenue to West Harrison Street; thence east on West Harrison Street to South Halsted Street; thence south on South Halsted Street to West Roosevelt Road; thence east on West Roosevelt Road to the place of beginning.

2-8-560  Twenty-sixth Ward.

The Twenty-sixth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of North Campbell Avenue and West Grand Avenue; thence northwest on West Grand Avenue to West Chicago Avenue; thence west on West Chicago Avenue to North Albany Avenue; thence north on North Albany Avenue to West Grand Avenue; thence northwest on West Grand Avenue to North Homan Avenue; thence southwest on North Homan Avenue to West Grand Avenue; thence northwest on West Grand Avenue to North Hamlin Avenue; thence north on North Hamlin Avenue to West North Avenue; thence east on West North Avenue to North Hamlin Avenue; thence north on North Hamlin Avenue to the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad; thence northwest on the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad to West Armitage Avenue; thence east on West Armitage Avenue to North Avers Avenue; thence north on North Avers Avenue to West Palmer Street; thence east on West Palmer Street to North Lawndale Avenue; thence north on North Lawndale Avenue to West Belden Avenue; thence east on West Belden Avenue to North Central Park Avenue; thence north on North Central Park Avenue to West Wrightwood Avenue; thence east on West Wrightwood Avenue to North Kimball Avenue; thence south on North Kimball Avenue to West Belden Avenue; thence east on West Belden Avenue to North Kedzie Avenue; thence north on North Kedzie Avenue to West Fullerton Avenue; thence east on West Fullerton Avenue to North Kedzie Boulevard; thence north on North Kedzie Boulevard to North Albany Avenue; thence east, southeast and south on North Albany Avenue to West Belden Avenue; thence west on West Belden Avenue to North Kedzie Boulevard; thence south on North Kedzie Boulevard to the centerline of West Palmer Square; thence west on the centerline of West Palmer Square to North Kedzie Boulevard; thence south on North Kedzie Boulevard and North Kedzie Avenue to West Dickens Avenue; thence west on West Dickens Avenue to North Kimball Avenue; thence south on North Kimball Avenue to West Armitage Avenue; thence west on West Armitage Avenue to North St. Louis Avenue; thence south on North St. Louis Avenue to West Cortland Street; thence east on West Cortland Street to the westernmost lanes of North Humboldt Boulevard; thence south on the westernmost lanes of North Humboldt Boulevard to West North Avenue; thence east on West North Avenue to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Le Moyne Street; thence east on West Le Moyne Street to North Artesian Avenue; thence south on North Artesian Avenue to West Hirsch Street; thence east on West Hirsch Street to North Western Avenue; thence south on North Western Avenue to West Haddon Avenue; thence west on West Haddon Avenue to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Thomas Street; thence west on West Thomas Street to North Rockwell Street; thence north on North Rockwell Street to West Haddon Avenue; thence west on West Haddon Avenue to North California Avenue; thence south on North California Avenue to West Augusta Boulevard; thence east on West Augusta Boulevard to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Iowa Street; thence west on West Iowa Street to North Rockwell Street; thence south on North Rockwell Street to West Chicago Avenue; thence east on West Chicago Avenue to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Huron Street; thence east on West Huron Street to North Western Avenue; thence south on North Western Avenue to West Erie Street; thence east on West Erie Street to North Damen Avenue; thence south on North Damen Avenue to West Race Avenue; thence east on West Race Avenue to North Wolcott Avenue; thence north on North Wolcott Avenue to West Ohio Street; thence east on West Ohio Street to North Ashland Avenue; thence north on North Ashland Avenue to West Erie Street; thence east on West Erie Street to North Armour Street; thence south on North Armour Street to West Hubbard Street; thence west on West Hubbard Street to North Campbell Avenue; thence north on North Campbell Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-39; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1; Amend Coun. J. 1-14-04, p. 17250, § 14)

2-8-570  Twenty-seventh Ward.

The Twenty-seventh Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of West Jackson Boulevard and South Loomis Street; thence north on South Loomis Street to West Madison Street; thence west on West Madison Street to South Paulina Street; thence south on South Paulina Street to West Monroe Street; thence west on West Monroe Street to South Damen Avenue; thence north on South Damen Avenue to West Lake Street; thence west on West Lake Street to the centerline of the Chicago and North Western Railroad; thence south on the centerline of the Chicago and North Western Railroad to West Maypole Avenue; thence west on West Maypole Avenue to North California Avenue; thence north on North California Avenue to West Walnut Street; thence west on West Walnut Street to North Albany Avenue; thence south on North Albany Avenue to West Washington Boulevard; thence west on West Washington Boulevard to North Kedzie Avenue; thence north on North Kedzie Avenue to north frontage roadway of West Franklin Boulevard; thence west on north frontage roadway of West Franklin Boulevard to North Homan Avenue; thence south on North Homan Avenue to Chicago and North Western Railroad; thence west on Chicago and North Western Railroad to North Hamlin Avenue; thence south on North Hamlin Avenue to West Lake Street; thence west on West Lake Street to North Pulaski Road; thence north on North Pulaski Road to West Thomas Street; thence west on West Thomas Street to North Karlov Avenue; thence north on North Karlov Avenue to West Hirsch Street; thence east on West Hirsch Street to West Grand Avenue; thence southeast on West Grand Avenue to North Albany Avenue; thence south on North Albany Avenue to West Chicago Avenue; thence east on West Chicago Avenue to West Grand Avenue; thence southeast on West Grand Avenue to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Hubbard Street; thence east on West Hubbard Street to North Armour Street; thence north on North Armour Street to West Erie Street; thence west on West Erie Street to North Ashland Avenue; thence north on North Ashland Avenue to West Chicago Avenue; thence east on West Chicago Avenue to North Greenview Avenue; thence north on North Greenview Avenue to West Walton Street; thence west on West Walton Street to North Ashland Avenue; thence north on North Ashland Avenue to West Thomas Street; thence east on West Thomas Street to North Milwaukee Avenue; thence northwest on North Milwaukee Avenue to West Division Street; thence east on West Division Street to the centerline of the north branch of the Chicago River; thence south on the centerline of the north branch of the Chicago River to North Halsted Street; thence north on North Halsted Street to West North Avenue; thence east on West North Avenue to North Larrabee Street; thence south on North Larrabee Street to North Clybourn Avenue; thence southeast on North Clybourn Avenue to North Schick Place; thence northeast on North Schick Place to North Cleveland Avenue; thence north on North Cleveland Avenue to West Blackhawk Street; thence east on West Blackhawk Street to North Sedgwick Street; thence north on North Sedgwick Street to West North Avenue; thence east on West North Avenue to North Wells Street; thence south on North Wells Street to West Schiller Street; thence west on West Schiller Street to the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority; thence east on the centerline of West Palmer Square to North Kedzie Boulevard; thence north on North Kedzie Boulevard to West Belden Avenue; thence east on West Belden Avenue to North Albany Avenue; thence north, northwest and west on North Albany Avenue to North Kedzie Boulevard; thence south on North Kedzie Boulevard to West Fullerton Avenue; thence west on West Fullerton Avenue to North Kedzie Avenue; thence south on North Kedzie Avenue to West Belden Avenue; thence west on West Belden Avenue to North Kimball Avenue; thence north on North Kimball Avenue to West Wrightwood Avenue; thence west on West Wrightwood Avenue to North Central Park Avenue; thence south on North Central Park Avenue to West Belden Avenue; thence west on West Belden Avenue to North Lawndale Avenue; thence south on North Lawndale Avenue to West Palmer Street; thence west on West Palmer Street to North Avers Avenue; thence north on North Avers Avenue to West Diversey Avenue; thence east on West Diversey Avenue to North Lawndale Avenue; thence north on North Lawndale Avenue to West Wolfram Street; thence east on West Wolfram Street to North Central Park Avenue; thence north on North Central Park Avenue to West Oakdale Avenue; thence west and northwest on West Oakdale Avenue to North Ridgeway Avenue; thence northeast on North Ridgeway Avenue to North Milwaukee Avenue; thence northwest on North Milwaukee Avenue to North Ridgeway Avenue; thence north on North Ridgeway Avenue to West School Avenue; thence east on West School Avenue to North Lawndale Avenue; thence north on North Lawndale Avenue and North Lawndale Avenue extended to the centerline of the John F. Kennedy Expressway (I-90); thence northeast on the centerline of the John F. Kennedy Expressway (I-90) to the extension of North Ridgeway Avenue; thence north on the extension of North Ridgeway Avenue to North Parkview Terrace; thence southeast on North Parkview Terrace to West Waveland Avenue; thence east on West Waveland Avenue to North Monticello Avenue; thence north on North Monticello Avenue to West Byron Street; thence east on West Byron Street to North Central Park Avenue; thence north on North Central Park Avenue to North Elston Avenue; thence southeast on North Elston Avenue to North Drake Avenue; thence north on North Drake Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-48; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1; Amend Coun. J. 1-14-04, p. 17243, § 2; Amend Coun. J. 1-14-04, p. 17250, § 19)

2-8-660  Thirty-sixth Ward.

The Thirty-sixth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of North Octavia Avenue and West Grace Street; thence east on West Grace Street to North Oak Park Avenue; thence south on North Oak Park Avenue to West Addison Street; thence east on West Addison Street to North Melvina Avenue; thence south on North Melvina Avenue to West Roscoe Street; thence east on West Roscoe Street to North Austin Avenue; thence south on North Austin Avenue to West Barry Avenue; thence west on West Barry Avenue to North Melvina Avenue; thence south on North Melvina Avenue to West Wellington Avenue; thence west on West Wellington Avenue to North Narragansett Avenue; thence south on North Narragansett Avenue to West North Avenue (city limit line); thence west and north following the city limit line to West Lawrence Avenue; thence east on West Lawrence Avenue to Illinois Route 171 (city limit line); thence south on Illinois Route 171 (city limit line) to West Montrose Avenue (city limit line); thence east on West Montrose Avenue (city limit line) to North Thatcher Road (city limit line); thence south on North Thatcher Road (city limit line) and West Pioneer Avenue (city limit line) to Illinois Route 19; thence east on Illinois Route 19 to North Octavia Avenue; thence south on North Octavia Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-49; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-710  Forty-first Ward.

The Forty-first Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of West Devon Avenue and the centerline of the Edens Expressway (I-94); thence south on the centerline of the Edens Expressway (I-94) to the extension of West Hiawatha Avenue; thence northwest on the extension of West Hiawatha Avenue and on West Hiawatha Avenue to North Le Mai Avenue; thence southwest on North Le Mai Avenue to West Leoti Avenue; thence northwest on West Leoti Avenue to North Spokane Avenue; thence northeast on North Spokane Avenue to West Devon Avenue; thence west on West Devon Avenue to North Minnehaha Avenue; thence northeast on North Minnehaha Avenue to West Tahoma Avenue; thence northwest on West Tahoma Avenue to North Central Avenue; thence southwest on North Central Avenue to the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad; thence southeast on the centerline of the Soo Line Railroad to the centerline of the north branch of the Chicago River; thence west and north following the centerline of the north branch of the Chicago River to West Devon Avenue; thence west on West Devon Avenue to North Nagle Avenue; thence south on North Nagle Avenue to the point where the city limit line extends west along the north boundary of Harwood Heights; thence west on the city limit line and following the city limit line to the intersection of North East River Road and West Lawrence Avenue; thence west on West Lawrence Avenue to the Des Plaines River (city limit line); thence north along the Des Plaines River (city limit line) and following the city limit line to West Foster Avenue (city limit line); thence west on West Foster Avenue (city limit line) to the boundary line of Chicago O'Hare International Airport; thence south following the city Limit line as said city limit line circumscribes Chicago O'Hare International Airport; thence east continuing to follow the city Limit line to the Des Plaines River (city limit line); thence north along the Des Plaines River (city limit line) and following the city limit line to the place of beginning (except that part thereof in unincorporated Cook County).

(Prior code § 4-54; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-780  Forty-eighth Ward.

The Forty-eighth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of West Foster Avenue and North Clark Street; thence north on North Clark Street to West Hood Avenue; thence east on West Hood Avenue to North Greenview Avenue; thence north on North Greenview Avenue to West Granville Avenue; thence east on West Granville Avenue to North Glenwood Avenue; thence north on North Glenwood Avenue to West Rosemont Avenue; thence east on West Rosemont Avenue to North Broadway; thence south on North Broadway to West Granville Avenue; thence east on West Granville Avenue to the centerline of the right- of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority; thence north on the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority to West Sheridan Road; thence east on West Sheridan Road to North Kenmore Avenue; thence south on North Kenmore Avenue to West Rosemont Avenue; thence east on West Rosemont Avenue to North Sheridan Road; thence south on North Sheridan Road to West Granville Avenue; thence east on West Granville Avenue extended to the shore of Lake Michigan; thence south following the shore of Lake Michigan to West Lawrence Drive extended east; thence West and west on West Lawrence Drive and West Lawrence Avenue to North Sheridan Road; thence north on North Sheridan Road to West Winona Street; thence west on West Winona Street to North Kenmore Avenue; thence south on North Kenmore Avenue to West Ainslie Street; thence west on West Ainslie Street to the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority; thence south on the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority to West Leland Avenue; thence west on West Leland Avenue to North Racine Avenue; thence north on North Racine Avenue to West Lawrence Avenue; thence west on West Lawrence Avenue to North Magnolia Avenue; thence north on North Magnolia Avenue to West Argyle Street; thence west on West Argyle Street to North Glenwood Avenue; thence north on North Glenwood Avenue to West Winnemac Avenue; thence east on West Winnemac Avenue to North Broadway; thence north on North Broadway to West Foster Avenue; thence west on West Foster Avenue to North Glenwood Avenue; thence south on North Glenwood Avenue to West Winona Street; thence west on West Winona Street to North Clark Street; thence south on North Clark Street to West Carmen Avenue; thence west on West Carmen Avenue to North Ashland Avenue; thence north on North Ashland Avenue to West Foster Avenue; thence east on West Foster Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-61; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-790  Forty-ninth Ward.

The Forty-ninth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of West Columbia Avenue and North Ridge Boulevard; thence north on North Ridge Boulevard to West Touhy Avenue; thence west on West Touhy Avenue to North Western Avenue; thence north on North Western Avenue to West Howard Street; thence east on West Howard Street to the city limit line; thence northwest and east on the city limit line to the shore of Lake Michigan; thence south following the shore of Lake Michigan to West Granville Avenue; thence west on West Granville Avenue to North Sheridan Road; thence north on North Sheridan Road to West Rosemont Avenue; thence west on West Rosemont Avenue to North Kenmore Avenue; thence north on North Kenmore Avenue to West Sheridan Road; thence west on West Sheridan Road to the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority; thence south on the centerline of the right-of- way of the Chicago Transit Authority to West Granville Avenue; thence west on West Granville Avenue to North Broadway; thence north on North Broadway to North Sheridan Road; thence north of North Sheridan Road to the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority; thence northwest on the centerline of the right-of-way of the Chicago Transit Authority to North Lakewood Avenue; thence north on North Lakewood Avenue to West Columbia Avenue; thence west on West Columbia Avenue to North Glenwood Avenue; thence north on North Glenwood Avenue to West Pratt Boulevard; thence west on West Pratt Boulevard to North Ashland Avenue; thence south on North Ashland Avenue to West Wallen Avenue; thence west on West Wallen Avenue to North Ravenswood Avenue; thence north on North Ravenswood Avenue to West Columbia Avenue; thence west on West Columbia Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-62; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1; Amend Coun. J. 1-14-04, p. 17250, § 23)

2-8-800  Fiftieth Ward.

The Fiftieth Ward shall be all that portion of the city bounded as follows:

Beginning at the intersection of North Western Avenue and West Touhy Avenue; thence east on West Touhy Avenue to North Ridge Boulevard; thence southeast on North Ridge Boulevard to West Columbia Avenue; then east on West Columbia Avenue to North Ravenswood Avenue; thence south on North Ravenswood Avenue to West Devon Avenue; thence west on West Devon Avenue to North Ravenswood Avenue (west); thence south on North Ravenswood Avenue (west) to West Granville Avenue; thence west on West Granville Avenue to North Oakley Avenue; thence south on North Oakley Avenue to West Glenlake Avenue; thence west on West Glenlake Avenue to North Campbell Avenue; thence south on North Campbell Avenue to West Peterson Avenue; thence west on West Peterson Avenue to North Lawndale Avenue; thence north on North Lawndale Avenue to West Granville Avenue; thence west on West Granville Avenue to North Ridgeway Avenue; thence north on North Ridgeway to West Devon Avenue (city limit line); thence east on West Devon Avenue to North Kedzie Avenue; thence north on North Kedzie Avenue to West Howard Street (city limit line); thence east on West Howard Street to North Western Avenue; thence south on North Western Avenue to the place of beginning.

(Prior code § 4-63; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

2-8-810  Map of ward boundaries.

For the purpose of more definitely fixing the boundaries of said wards of the city, there is attached hereto an outline map of the city showing the boundaries of said wards as herein before described and the same is made a part of this Code.

(Prior code § 4-64; Amendment adopted by referendum, 3-17-92; Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

ARTICLE IV.  LEGISLATIVE REFERENCE BUREAU

2-8-820  Establishment and supervision.

There is hereby created and established a legislative reference bureau which shall be known as the “city council legislative reference bureau”. The said bureau shall be under the supervision of a director who shall be appointed by the committee on committees and rules of the city council, and be subject to its control, supervision and direction.

(Prior code Ch. 198.8A, § 1)

2-8-830  Director's assistants.

The director shall appoint his technical and clerical assistants in such number and for such compensation as may be provided in the annual appropriation ordinance.

(Prior code Ch. 198.8A, § 2)

2-8-840  Office location and hours.

The office of the bureau shall be established in the City Hall building and shall be located as near as may be possible to the chamber of the city council. It shall be open daily excepting Sundays and legal holidays, including all hours during which the city council is in session.

(Prior code Ch. 198.8A, § 3)

2-8-850  Powers and duties.

It shall be the duty of said bureau:

(a) To prepare, upon the request of any member of the city council, ordinances, resolutions and orders proposed to be introduced in the city council by said members, including amendments, substitutes and revisions of existing or proposed ordinances, resolutions and orders;

(b) To collect, catalogue, classify, index, completely digest, topically index, checklist and summarize all ordinances, resolutions and orders as well as amendments or revisions thereof, if any, introduced in the city council, as soon as practicable after the same have been printed, and to furnish copies of the digest, indexed and topically indexed, to each member of the city council after each meeting of the city council;

(c) To collect, assemble and catalogue in such manner as may make the same readily accessible, the ordinances, resolutions, orders and laws of other cities and municipal corporations, and such other printed or written material as may aid the members of the city council in the performance of their duties.

(Prior code Ch. 198.8A, § 4)

2-8-860  Cooperating departments.

The board of directors of the Chicago Public Library and the department of law shall cooperate with the reference bureau and shall be authorized to loan to said bureau any books, periodicals, documents or other printed data belonging to their respective offices.

(Prior code Ch. 198.8A, § 5; Amend Coun. J. 12-13-00, p. 48076, § 2)

Ward Redistricting Ordinance*

* Editor's note – The following map was set forth in Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1. Note that there may have been amendments to this map since it was published in 2001.

To view a PDF, printer-friendly version, click here


(Amend Coun. J. 12-19-01, p. 76725, § 1)

CHAPTER 2-12
CITY CLERK

2-12-010 Powers and duties.

2-12-020 Filing of ordinances.

2-12-030 License plates, badges, tags and emblems.

2-12-040 City code and amendments.

2-12-050 Journal of council proceedings.

2-12-060 Claims against the city.

2-12-070 Duplicate payroll records.

2-12-080 Deputy city clerk – Appointment – Powers and duties.

2-12-010  Powers and duties.

The city clerk shall, in addition to other duties imposed upon him by law, perform the following:

Report to the council (such report to be made a part of the official record) all acceptances of ordinances, and bonds connected therewith, which have been filed in his office since the preceding meeting;

Issue notices to the members of the city council when directed so to do by that body, also to the members of the different committees and to all persons whose attendance is required before any committee, when directed or requested so to do by the chairman of such committee;

Upon the filing of a call for any special meeting, prepare notices of such meeting and cause them to be served on the members of the city council not later than the calendar day next preceding the day set for such special meeting; provided, that in a case of extreme emergency or in case of the death of a member of the city council such notices may be served on the day of the meeting. Notices of special meetings shall specify in brief the objects or purposes for which they shall have been called;

Deliver without delay to the officers of the city, and to all committees of the city council, all resolutions and communications referred to such officers or committees by that body;

Deliver without delay to the mayor all ordinances or resolutions in his charge which may require to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the mayor, together with all papers on which the same are founded;

Attest all licenses granted under the provisions of this Code and keep record of the issuance thereof;

Administer and enforce the dog licensing requirements of this Code, which shall include the authority to issue citations for violations;

Administer and enforce the requirements of Chapter 3-56 and other provisions of this Code relating to the wheel tax license emblem, which shall include the authority to issue citations for violations;

Keep the corporate seal and affix same to all documents and papers that are required to bear the official seal of the city.

(Prior code § 5-1; Amend Coun. J. 12-12-01, p. 75777, § 4.5; Amend Coun. J. 12-8-04, p. 38063, § 1; Amend Coun. J. 2-15-12, p. 20533, § 1)

2-12-020  Filing of ordinances.

The originals of all ordinances passed by the city council shall be filed in the city clerk's office.

(Prior code § 5-2)

2-12-030  License plates, badges, tags and emblems.

The city clerk shall deliver all license plates, badges, tags, or emblems to the licensee in accordance with Section 4-4-200, and Chapters 3-56 and 7-12 of this Code.

(Prior code § 5-3; Amend Coun. J. 6-13-07, p. 2873, § 1)

2-12-040  City code and amendments.

The city clerk shall maintain correct copies of this Code as amended in accordance with Section 1-4-050.

(Prior code § 5-4)

2-12-050  Journal of council proceedings.

The city clerk shall keep the journal of the proceedings of the city council in printed form, and shall sign his name at the foot of the journal for each meeting of the city council. From time to time he shall have the journal for a series of consecutive meetings bound together into book form for permanent filing.

The city clerk shall cause copies of the journal of the proceedings of each meeting of the city council to be printed and published in pamphlet form as soon after the close of each meeting as conveniently may be, and shall as often as annually cause a limited number of such pamphlet copies for successive meetings of the city council to be bound into permanent book form together with an index thereto, for convenient reference. Such printed pamphlet copies of the journal shall carry an inscription or legend showing that they are published by authority of the city council. All ordinances passed by the city council which are required by statute to be published in pamphlet form before taking effect shall be printed in full text in such published pamphlet copies of the journal of the proceedings of the city council for the respective council meetings.

The city clerk shall provide duplicate copies of the journal of proceedings to members of the city council and the departments and agencies of the city government without charge. The city clerk shall have authority to charge a reasonable fee for providing a single duplicate copy of any journal of proceedings to persons outside the city government. The fee shall be based on the cost of duplicating the journal of proceedings, but shall not exceed the charges allowable under the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, as amended. The city clerk may also provide copies of the journal of proceedings to any person outside the city government who requests copies on a subscription basis. The fee for an annual subscription shall be $600.00, to cover duplication costs, postage or other delivery charges incurred by the clerk, and the cost of maintaining subscription records. No duplication or subscription fee shall be charged to educational, charitable, religious, eleemosynary or veterans' organizations that are organized on a not-for-profit basis. Fees due under this section shall be paid to the department of finance.

(Prior code § 5-5; Amend Coun. J. 2-9-94, p. 45017; Amend Coun. J. 11-16-11, p. 13798, Art. I, § 2)

2-12-060  Claims against the city.

The city clerk shall deliver without delay to the committee on finance of the city council all statements of claims against the city which he shall receive from the members of the public at large.  Such statements shall be printed legibly and neatly on approved forms before submission to the city clerk.

(Prior code § 5-6; Added Coun. J. 12-7-84, p. 11597; Amend Coun. J. 2-6-08, p. 19931, § 2)

2-12-070  Duplicate payroll records.

The city clerk is authorized to destroy all duplicate payrolls more than two years old.

(Prior code § 5-7)

2-12-080  Deputy city clerk – Appointment – Powers and duties.

There is hereby created the office of deputy city clerk. The city clerk shall appoint said deputy city clerk who shall, during the disability or absence of the city clerk, have and exercise the powers and duties of the city clerk (except as restricted by law to be exercised by the city clerk only) and shall at all times have and exercise such powers and duties as may be assigned to him by the city clerk.

(Prior code § 5-8)

CHAPTER 2-14
DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS

Article I.  General Provisions

2-14-010 Department of administrative hearings – Establishment and composition.

2-14-030 Powers and duties of the director.

2-14-040 Administrative law officers – Powers and duties.

2-14-050 Administrative law officers – Training requirements.

2-14-060 Rules and regulations – Available for public inspection.

2-14-065 General provisions.

2-14-070 Instituting administrative adjudication proceedings.

2-14-072 Adjudication by mail.

2-14-074 Notice.

2-14-076 Administrative hearings.

2-14-078 Default.

2-14-080 Subpoenas.

2-14-090 Compliance bond.

2-14-100 Violations of orders.

2-14-101 Seized / unclaimed property.

2-14-102 Review under the administrative review law.

2-14-103 Enforcement of administrative law officer's order.

2-14-104 Interest.

2-14-105 Fines payable to the department of finance.

2-14-108 Petition to set aside default order.

2-14-109 Petition by city department for relief from a final order of liability entered in error.

2-14-110 Election of remedies.

2-14-120 Administrative adjudication procedures not exclusive.

2-14-130 Other provisions not limiting.

2-14-132 Impoundment.

2-14-135 Impoundment – Towing and storage fee hearing.

Article II.  Vehicle Hearings Division

2-14-140 Vehicle hearings division.

Article III.  Buildings Hearings Division

2-14-150 Buildings hearings division.

2-14-151 Definitions.

2-14-152 Service of notice to building owner.

2-14-154 Rights of occupants.

2-14-155 Defenses to building code violations.

2-14-156 Separate hearings on the imposition of fines and other sanctions.

Article IV.  Environmental Safety and Consumer Affairs Hearings Division

2-14-160 Environmental safety and consumer affairs hearings division.

Article V.  Reserved

Article VI.  Municipal Hearings Division

2-14-190 Municipal hearings division – Jurisdiction.

2-14-195 Fine of $10,000.00 or more – Petition for review to the director.

2-14-200 Eviction proceedings.

ARTICLE I.  GENERAL PROVISIONS

2-14-010  Department of administrative hearings – Establishment and composition.

There is hereby established an office of the municipal government to be known as the department of administrative hearings which shall be authorized to conduct administrative adjudication proceedings for departments and agencies of the city, and for other units of government acting pursuant to intergovernmental agreements with the city.

The department shall be administered by a director, who shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the city council, and staffed by administrative law officers and other employees as may be provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance.

The provisions of Division 2.1 of Article 1 of the Illinois Municipal Code are hereby adopted and incorporated into this chapter as if fully set forth herein.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564; Amend Coun. J. 2-15-12, p. 20496, § 4)

2-14-030  Powers and duties of the director.

The powers and duties of the director of the department of administrative hearings shall include:

(1) directing the department with respect to its management and structure, including the creation or reorganization of hearing divisions within the department;

(2) appointing and removing administrative law officers, as necessary;

(3) promulgating rules and regulations for the conduct of administrative adjudication proceedings;

(4) monitoring and supervising the work of administrative law officers and, upon receipt of a timely petition for review authorized by the code, reviewing, modifying or reversing their decisions;

(5) establishing a system for hearing of grievances brought by tenants of the Chicago Housing Authority against the authority and/or its property managers, all in accordance with an intergovernmental agreement between the City of Chicago and the Chicago Housing Authority; and

(6) establishing systems for adjudicating matters pursuant to intergovernmental agreements entered into between the City of Chicago and other units of government; and

(7) establishing any other necessary rules and regulations as may be required to carry out the provisions of this chapter.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564; Amend Coun. J. 3-31-04, p. 20968, § 1; Amend Coun. J. 2-15-12, p. 20496, § 4)

2-14-040  Administrative law officers – Powers and duties.

Each administrative law officer appointed by the director shall be an attorney admitted to the practice of law in the State of Illinois for at least three years. Administrative law officers shall have all powers necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings including, but not limited to, the power to:

(1) hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues;

(2) administer oaths and affirmations;

(3) hear testimony;

(4) rule upon motions, objections, and the admissibility of evidence;

(5) subject to the restrictions contained in Section 2-14-080, at the request of any party or on the administrative law officer's own motion, subpoena the attendance of relevant witnesses and the production of relevant books, records, or other information;

(6) preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;

(7) regulate the course of the hearing in accordance with this chapter, the rules adopted by the department for the conduct of administrative hearings, or other applicable law;

(8) discuss administrative adjudication proceedings with their supervisors;

(9) issue a final order which includes findings of fact and conclusions of law;

(10) impose penalties and fines and issue orders that are consistent with applicable code provisions and assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation; provided, however, that in no event shall an administrative law officer have the authority to: (i) impose a penalty of imprisonment; or (ii) except in cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the city, in which this limitation shall not apply, impose a fine in excess of $50,000 exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with this Code; and

(11) in any case in which a party has sought review by the department of administrative hearings of an order or determination of another city department or agency, when such review is authorized by this Code, assess costs upon affirming the order or determination.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-050  Administrative law officers – Training requirements.

Prior to conducting any administrative adjudication proceeding, an administrative law officer shall have successfully completed a formal training program, approved by the director, which includes the following:

(1) instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings which he or she will conduct;

(2) orientation to each subject area of the code violations which he or she will adjudicate;

(3) observation of administrative hearings; and

(4) participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuing final orders.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-060  Rules and regulations – Available for public inspection.

The rules and regulations promulgated for the conduct of administrative adjudication proceedings shall be published and kept on file in the office of the director where they shall be available to the public for inspection and copying during normal business hours.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-065  General provisions.

The provisions of this article shall apply to administrative adjudication proceedings conducted by the department of administrative hearings to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code which set forth specific procedures for the administrative adjudication of particular code provisions.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-070  Instituting administrative adjudication proceedings.

Any authorized department or agency of the city may institute an administrative adjudication proceeding with the department of administrative hearings by forwarding a copy of a notice of violation or a notice of hearing, which has been properly served, to the department of administrative hearings.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-072  Adjudication by mail.

The rules adopted by the director for the conduct of administrative adjudication proceedings may provide that a respondent may elect to contest an alleged violation through an adjudication by mail rather than at an administrative hearing.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-074  Notice.

(a) Before any administrative adjudication proceeding may be conducted, the parties shall be afforded notice in compliance with this section.

(b) Unless otherwise provided by law or rule, the issuer of a notice of violation or notice of hearing shall specify on the notice his or her name and department; where known, the name and address of the person or entity charged with the violation; the date, time and place of the violation; and the section of the code or departmental rule or regulation which was allegedly violated; and shall certify the correctness of the specified information by signing his or her name to the notice. A notice of hearing shall also include the date, time and location of the hearing and the penalties for failure to appear at the hearing.

(c) Unless otherwise provided by law or rule, a notice of violation or notice of hearing shall be served upon the alleged violator no less than seven calendar days prior to the date of the hearing: (i) by first class or express mail or by overnight carrier at the violator's residence address or, if the violator is a business entity, at any address identified for its registered agent or at its principal place of business; or (ii) by personal service, including personal service upon an employee or agent of the alleged violator at a place of business of the alleged violator or otherwise if such service is reasonably calculated to give the alleged violator actual notice; or (iii) if service cannot be made by either of (i) or (ii) above, when the alleged violator is the owner or manager of the property by posting a copy of the violation notice on the front entrance of the building or other structure where the violation is found, or if the property is unimproved or fenced off, by posting a copy of the violation notice in a prominent place upon the property where the violation is found.

(d) In all non-emergency situations, if requested by the defendant, the defendant shall have at least 15 days after the date of mailing or other service of a notice of violation or notice of hearing to prepare for a hearing. For purposes of this section, “non-emergency situation” means any situation that does not reasonably constitute a threat to the public interest, safety or welfare.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-076  Administrative hearings.

(a) Any administrative adjudication proceeding conducted by the department of administrative hearings shall afford the parties an opportunity for a hearing before an administrative law officer.

(b) An attorney who appears on behalf of any person shall file with the administrative law officer a written appearance on a form provided by the department of administrative hearings for such purpose.

(c) In no event shall the case for the city be presented by an employee of the department of administrative hearings; provided, however, that documentary evidence, including the notice of violation, which has been prepared by another department or agency of the city, may be presented at the hearing by the administrative law officer.

(d) The administrative law officer may grant continuances only upon a finding of good cause.

(e) All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation.

(f) The administrative law officer may issue subpoenas to secure the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and the production of relevant documents. Issuance of subpoenas shall be subject to the restrictions contained in Section 2-14-080.

(g) Subject to subsection (j) of this section, the administrative law officer may permit witnesses to submit their testimony by affidavit or by telephone.

(h) The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply in the conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.

(i) No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence; provided, however, that a violation notice, or a copy thereof, issued and signed in accordance with 2-14-074 shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts specified therein.

(j) Upon the timely request of any party to the proceeding, any person, who the administrative law officer determines may reasonably be expected to provide testimony which is material and which does not constitute a needless presentation of cumulative evidence, shall be made available for cross-examination prior to a final determination of liability.

(k) The record of all hearings before an administrative law officer shall include: (i) a record of the testimony presented at the hearing, which may be made by tape recording or other appropriate means; (ii) all documents presented at the hearing; (iii) a copy of the notice of violation or notice of hearing; and (iv) a copy of the findings and decision of the administrative law officer.

(l) Upon conclusion of a hearing, the administrative law officer shall issue a final determination of liability or no liability. Upon issuing a final determination of liability the administrative law officer may: (i) impose penalties and/or fines that are consistent with applicable provisions of the Municipal Code; (ii) issue orders that are consistent with applicable provisions of the Municipal Code; and/or (iii) assess costs reasonably related to instituting the administrative adjudication proceeding; provided, however, that in no event shall the administrative law officer have the authority to impose a penalty of imprisonment or, except in cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the city, where this limitation shall not apply, impose a fine in excess of $50,000.00 exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with this Code.

(m) In the issuance of a final determination of liability, an administrative law officer shall inform the respondent of his or her right to seek judicial review of the final determination.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-078  Default.

(a) If at the time set for a hearing the recipient of a notice of violation or a notice of hearing, or his or her attorney of record, fails to appear, the administrative law officer may find the recipient in default and proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation and conclude with a finding, decision, and order. A copy of the order of default shall be served in any manner permitted by Section 2-14-074(c).

(b) The recipient of a notice of violation or a notice of hearing who is found to be in default may petition the administrative law officer to set aside the order of default and set a new hearing date in accordance with Section 2-14-108.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-080  Subpoenas.

(a) An administrative law officer may issue a subpoena only if he or she determines that the testimony of the witnesses or the documents or items sought by the subpoena are necessary to present evidence that is:

(i) relevant to the case; and

(ii) relates to a contested issue in the case.

(b) A subpoena issued under this chapter shall identify:

(i) the person to whom it is directed;

(ii) the documents or other items sought by the subpoena, if any;

(iii) the date for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena;

(iv) the time for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena; and

(v) the place for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena.

(c) In no event shall the date identified for the appearance of the witnesses or the production of the documents or other items be less than seven days after service of the subpoena.

(d) Within three business days of being served with a subpoena issued in accordance with this chapter, the recipient of the subpoena may appeal the order authorizing the issuance of the subpoena to an administrative law officer, who shall not be the same administrative law officer who ordered the issuance of the subpoena.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-090  Compliance bond.

In order to ensure that code violations are remedied or fines are paid in a timely manner, an administrative law officer, upon issuing a final determination of liability, may require a code violator to post with the city a compliance bond or, as appropriate, to consent to the granting and recording of a lien against titled property. Bonds and liens shall be approved by the city comptroller and the corporation counsel as to form and amount. Whenever it is necessary for the city to make repairs or otherwise expend funds relating to a code violation for which a bond was posted, or whenever fines or costs remain unpaid after a code violator has exhausted or failed to exhaust judicial review procedures, the administrative law officer may, after giving the parties notice and opportunity to be heard, issue an order permitting the city to draw against the bond in an appropriate amount, or to foreclose on the lien. The administrative law officer shall order the bond or the titled property or proceeds from the titled property, less the costs incurred by the city, returned to the code violator upon proof of compliance with the applicable code provisions and the payment of applicable fines or costs.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-100  Violations of orders.

(a) Elements of the offense. A person violates this section if he or she:

(1) receives notice and an opportunity to be heard under this Code; and

(2) knowingly fails to comply with an order issued by an administrative law officer under this chapter, including any requirement of a subpoena.

Each day that the violation occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct offense.

(b) Defenses. It shall be an affirmative defense to this section that a court of competent jurisdiction stayed the order issued by the administrative law officer prior to the effective date of the order.

(c) Prohibited defenses. It is not a defense to this section that a person:

(1) came into compliance or attempted to come into compliance with the order after the date the order by its terms required compliance; or

(2) sought judicial review of the order but failed to obtain a stay of the order prior to the date the order by its terms required compliance.

(d) Sentence. A person convicted under this section shall be punished by:

(1) a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $500.00 for each offense;

(2) incarceration for not more than 180 days for each offense; and/or

(3) an order to perform community service for a period not to exceed 200 hours for each offense.

However, whenever the order giving rise to the offense is an order of abatement pursuant to Chapter 7-4, Section 8-4-090 or Section 13-12-145 of this Code, the sentence shall include a mandatory minimum sentence of no less than four days incarceration.

(e) Venue. The corporation counsel shall institute actions under this section in a court of competent jurisdiction.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564; Amend Coun. J. 8-30-00, p. 40306, § 4)

2-14-101  Seized / unclaimed property.

After an administrative law officer has issued a final determination of liability or no liability, any property seized by the city in relation to the subject matter of the final determination of liability or no liability that is not forfeited by operation of law may be reclaimed by the lawful owner provided that all penalties and fees have been paid. The procedures for the reclamation shall be within the discretion of the department head of the city department or agency charged with maintaining custody of the property. After the expiration of time during which judicial review of the final determination of liability may be sought or 35 days after the final determination of no liability, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any property not so reclaimed may be disposed of by the city department or agency charged with maintaining custody of the property as provided by law.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-102  Review under the Administrative Review Law.

Any final decision by the department of administrative hearings that a code violation does or does not exist shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law, except as otherwise may be provided by law for decisions issued prior to the effective date of this ordinance.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-103  Enforcement of administrative law officer's order.

(a) Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed by an administrative law officer's order that remain unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures shall be a debt due and owing the city and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law.

(b) After the expiration of the period in which judicial review may be sought, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision and order of an administrative law officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.

(c) In any case in which a respondent fails to comply with an administrative law officer's order to correct a code violation or imposing a fine or other sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by the city to enforce the administrative law officer's order, including but not limited to, attorney's fees, court costs and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or an administrative law officer shall be a debt due and owing the city. Prior to any expenses being fixed by an administrative law officer, the respondent shall be provided with notice that states that the respondent shall appear at a hearing before an administrative law officer to determine whether the respondent has failed to comply with the administrative law officer's order. The notice shall set the time for the hearing, which shall not be less than seven days from the date that notice is served. Notice shall be served by first class mail and the seven-day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was deposited in the mail.

(d) Upon being recorded in the manner required by Article XII of the Code of Civil Procedure or by the Uniform Commercial Code, a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the respondent in the amount of a debt due and owing the city. The lien may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.

(e) Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from enforcing or seeking to enforce any order of an administrative law officer in any manner which is in accordance with applicable law.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-104  Interest.

Except as otherwise provided by law, interest on any debt due and owing shall accrue at the rate set for interest upon judgments.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-105  Fines payable to the department of finance.

All fines and other monies paid to the city in accordance with this chapter shall be remitted to the department of finance.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564; Amend Coun. J. 11-16-11, p. 13798, Art. I, § 2)

2-14-108  Petition to set aside default order.

(a) An administrative law officer may set aside any order entered by default and set a new hearing date, upon a petition filed within 21 days after the issuance of the order of default, if the administrative law officer determines that the petitioner's failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or, at any time, if the petitioner establishes that the petitioner was not provided with proper service of process. If the petition is granted, the administrative law officer shall proceed with a new hearing on the underlying matter as soon as practical.

(b) If any order is set aside under this section, the administrative law officer shall have authority to enter an order extinguishing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due and owing as a result of the vacated default order and directing the city to refund any fines and/or penalties paid pursuant to the vacated order.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-109  Petition by city department for relief from a final order of liability entered in error.

(a) After an order of liability becomes final, the city department or agency which initiated or prosecuted an administrative adjudication before the department of administrative hearings may file a written petition for relief from a final order of liability entered in error with the department of administrative hearings.

(b) The written petition must be filed and signed by the department or agency head of the initiating or prosecuting department or agency and must set forth facts alleging that the order of liability: (1) was entered in error; (2) is unsupported by the record; (3) is inconsistent with applicable provisions of this Code; and (4) should be vacated to avoid a miscarriage of justice. The authority to file and sign a petition under this section is expressly reserved to the department or agency head and may not be delegated to other department or agency officials or personnel.

(c) Upon the filing of a written petition by a department or agency head, the director of administrative hearings shall schedule a hearing on the petition. The scope of the hearing shall be limited to the merits of the petition and shall not be expanded to constitute a re-litigation of the underlying notice of violation.

(d) If a petition is granted, the final order of liability shall be vacated. If an order is vacated under this section, the administrative law officer shall have authority to enter an order extinguishing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due and owing as a result of the vacated order and directing the city to refund any fines and/or penalties paid pursuant to the vacated order.

(Added Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-110  Election of remedies.

In no case may the department of administrative hearings conduct an administrative adjudication proceeding for an alleged violation of the Municipal Code where the requested remedy is a punishment of imprisonment; provided, however, where a violation of the code is punishable by fines and other penalties in addition to imprisonment, the city may elect to institute an action with the department of administrative hearings and thereby waive any imprisonment for the code violation. Nothing in this chapter, however, shall preclude the city from seeking the remedy of imprisonment in a court of law, including imprisonment for failure to comply with the order of an administrative law officer, pursuant to Section 2-14-100.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-120  Administrative adjudication procedures not exclusive.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, neither the authority of the department of administrative hearings to conduct administrative adjudication procedures nor the institution of such procedures under this chapter shall preclude the city from seeking any remedies for code violations through the use of any other administrative procedure or court proceeding.

(Added Coun. J. 7-10-96, p. 24982; Amend Coun. J. 11-12-97, p. 56813; Amend Coun. J. 4-29-98, p. 66564)

2-14-130  Other provisions not limiting.

(a) Notwithstanding any other provision of the Municipal Code, all provisions of the code, except for those specified in Section 2-14-190(a), may be enforced by instituting an administrative adjudication proceeding with the department of administrative hearings as provided in this chapter.

(b) Notwithstanding any other provision of the Municipal Code, any enforcement action which may be exercised by another department or agency of the city may also be exercised by the department of administrative hearings; provided, however, that the department shall not have authority to revoke or suspend any city license except those issued pursuant to Chapters 9-104, 9-108 and 9-112 of this Code.
